repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Recovery and
            Disaster Management Project for Haiti were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was high, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the baseline and outcome indicators of this project were not
            well defined. While the results framework suggests there
            were no committees at appraisal, the technical annex
            mentions that about 50 committees existed in one form or
            another in the 133 communes. Interviews with the local
            committees confirm that in some cases there was already a
            committee in place, although a solid structure was still
            lacking. The objectives, indicators and outcomes of this
            project made the quantitative measurement of the impact
            complicated. Similar projects will benefit from a
            well-prepared results framework with realistic and
            measurable indicators. It has been observed that the
            committees which include members from civil society are the
            highest performing and most dynamic committees. Moreover,
            strong leadership by municipal governments has proved to be
            even more essential. In the communes where the mayor feels a
            strong sense of ownership of the committee, committees have
            been engaged in a higher number and wider variety of
            activities. Over time, these projects have also been able to
            actively engage with other development actors.

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The restructuring of the Emergency
            Recovery and Disaster Management Project (ERDMP) is in
            response to request from the Government of the Republic of
            Haiti (GoH) to restructure the project following the
            earthquake of January 12, 2010 that resulted in over 230,000
            dead, 600,000 homeless and significant damage to public
            infrastructure and administrative capacities. Currently the
            ERDMP is the only mechanism at the GoH's disposal
            capable of providing immediate technical and financial
            support to the national civil protection authorities in the
            aftermath of the earthquake. The restructuring will be
            limited to: (i) an extension of the closing date of the
            project by twelve (12) months, specifically an extension of
            the closing date of both the Development Grant Agreement and
            the financing agreement until Dec 31, 2011; (ii) a
            reallocation between categories to cover existing and
            projected category expense overruns; (iii) the elimination
            of one minor subcomponent under part B4 of the project
            (related to the installation of a national communication
            system to coordinate the operations between the national and
            regional levels); and (iv) a revised results management framework.

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project : environmental report

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Emergency Recovery
            and Disaster Management Project of Haiti are 1): to assist
            in the rehabilitation of the areas affected by the recent
            adverse natural events. Satisfactory planning and completion
            of a rehabilitation scheme for affected settlements are key
            outcome indicators; 2) to strengthen the country's
            capacity to manage natural disaster risks and better respond
            to emergencies resulting from adverse natural events. The
            key outcomes for the capacity established within the DPC
            includes: (i) a validated legal framework;(ii) stronger
            management systems; (iii) improved technical capacity; and
            (iv) an operational, validated National Response Plan; 3) to
            reduce the vulnerability of communities through risk
            identification and mapping, and risk mitigation activities
            at the local level.. The potential negative environmental
            impacts overall under the Project can be: a) The survival
            strategies and the environment in rural Haiti are often
            complex, unpredictable and fragile; b) Some alternative
            lifestyles and better marketing of agricultural products
            (including livestock), resulting in improved well-being,
            could lead to greater demand on natural resources or
            environmental degradation; c) The introduction of investment
            in targeted areas may attract immigrants which would
            increase the pressure on existing resources and could lead
            to conflicts within the population; d) The introduction of
            alien plant species could affect the evolution of the
            biodiversity of the country; e) Deterioration of the
            landscape or movement of land through drainage works, soil
            conservation and road; and f) The procurement of materials
            for construction projects may affect the state of natural
            resources in certain areas.

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project (ERDMP) was prepared in response to the
            Government of Haiti's (GoH) request for post Tropical
            Storm Jeanne (2004) disaster recovery assistance. The
            Development Grant Agreement (H-1430-HA) was signed on
            January 6, 2005 and the project became effective on June 1,
            2005. The closing date is scheduled for December 31,2008.
            The project development objective of the ERDMP, as stated in
            the Development Grant Agreement is to support the GoH in the
            (i) rehabilitation of areas affected by recent adverse
            natural events, (ii) strengthening of the country's
            capacity to manage natural disaster risks and to better
            respond to emergencies resulting from adverse natural
            events; and (iii) reduction of the vulnerability of
            communities through risk mitigation activities. The goal is
            to bolster the environmental and social decision making
            framework so that the selected rehabilitation and risk
            mitigation micro-projects are environmentally sustainable.
            The updated Environmental Management Plan (EMP) will define
            the means of improving the impact of the sub-projects on the environment.

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency Recovery
            and Disaster Management Project is: (a) to support the
            rehabilitation of the areas affected by the recent adverse
            natural disasters; (b) to strengthen the country's
            capacity to manage natural disaster risks and better respond
            to emergencies resulting from adverse natural events; and
            (c) to reduce the vulnerability of communities through risk
            identification and risk mitigation activities. These
            objectives are consistent with one of the focal points of
            the Transitional Support Strategy (TSS) that outlines
            IDA'S strategy for Haiti over the next 24 months (FY05
            and FY06). The TSS explicitly incorporates the activities
            already submitted to the LICUS Trust Fund, including the
            proposed disaster reconstruction and mitigation initiatives.
            The TSS, being presented to the Board together with this
            proposed operation, also includes in the lending program the
            proposed Emergency Recovery and Disaster Management Project
            for US$12 million equivalent. The objectives are also
            consistent with the overall priorities on environmental
            management within the Interim Cooperation Framework (ICF).
            The longer term objectives of the Environment Thematic
            Group, in which IDA is an active participant, include the
            development of sustainable strategies to reverse resource
            degradation by introducing sustainable watershed management,
            reforestation and measures to reduce the impact of climatic hazards.
